So far this year 42 have been deposited; in 2018, 371 have been deposited." We decided to take a look at the numbers. Is it true that petitions and referendums are presented in "high records"? If so, what should we make of numbers? Borleson officials referred to the Office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Missouri as a source of his statements. His numbers have been checked. As of 13 February, the date of the statement, 42 petitions had been filed for the 2020 election cycle. In 2012, a total of 371 petitions for initiatives, mostly over the past 12 years, were submitted, according to data from the Office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Missouri. However, the number of petitions approved for circulation increased at a much slower rate. The number of measures taken in the voting has remained largely stable over the years. Why the rush? In order for the petition to reach the ballot, petitioners must first submit the proposed initiative petitions to the Office of the Secretary of State for review and approval for circulation. After obtaining permission to circulate a petition, they can then begin collecting signatures to place the measure on the ballot paper. Under the current law, petitioners are required to collect signatures from a certain percentage of legal voters in any of the eight provinces of Congress in Missouri. For those seeking legal changes, this figure is 5 per cent; for constitutional changes, it is 8 per cent. Only petitions that reach the mark with sufficiently verified signatures can be placed on the ballot paper. The measure will require a simple majority of the votes cast in the elections to eventually become law. "If it requires 5,000 signatures in the congressional area, to be safe, you may want to have 7,000 or 8,000 signatures in that area." Layton said that the districts in Missouri are now smaller than before, which has also made it more difficult to collect signatures to some extent. Hatfield thinks the current law "breaks the right balance." Under the current law, only ideas with a wide range of popular or financial support are allowed to vote.
